description: From Middle English portcolyse, from Old French porte colëice, from porte (“door”) + feminine of colëiz (“sliding”), ultimately from Latin colāre.

nouns.description: portcullis (plural portcullises or portcullisses or (rare) portculli or (rare) portscullis)

entries.meaning: A gate in the form of a grating which is lowered into place at the entrance to a castle, fort, etc.
(historical) An English coin of the reign of Elizabeth I, struck for the use of the East India Company, and bearing the figure of a portcullis on the reverse.

verbs.description: portcullis (third-person singular simple present portcullises or portcullisses, present participle portcullising or portcullissing, simple past and past participle portcullised or portcullissed)

entries.meaning: To obstruct with, or as with, a portcullis; to shut; to bar.
